intro: Didissandra delavayi, commonly known as the Chinese sand-dollar plant, is a unique member of the Araliaceae family. It is characterized by its distinctive, fleshy, sand-dollar-shaped fruits that are covered in a rough, warty texture. Native to the mountainous regions of Yunnan, Sichuan, and Tibet in China, this plant thrives in cool, moist environments. The leaves are typically alternate, with a lobed or palmate structure, and the plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers. Its unusual morphology and limited distribution make it a subject of interest in botanical studies and conservation efforts.
